reviewText:
Early Access Review

One man's trash is sometimes also trash

Full disclosure: review copy provided by developer/publisher!

Garbage Day is a new indie title with a really cool concept, so dig it: you're a shlub that lives in suburbia, workin' at the nuclear power plant. Everything is great until something goes wrong and you find yourself stuck in a temporal loop, reliving the same day over and over, again and again and again and again.

Ad infinitum.

Unless you find a way to break the cycle.

That's the concept... kind of like Groundhog Day meets Postal. And it's a great idea! But at this stage, for the asking price, Garbage Day leaves a LOT to be desired. You wake up in your bed at the start of the sandbox level and can do a few things. For example, you can: pour a bowl of cereal (though I can't for the life of me add milk), put a tape in your VCR, drive a car (there only appears to be the one), grab a bunch of weapons and go, well, postal (the police will respond but once the four of them are dead there's no real threat), you can kill yourself in sundry ways (thus starting the day over), and you can explore the relatively small sandbox.

And that's it, really. There's no single player campaign currently, just the one sandbox level. According to the screenshots there's, like, a snowy environment and a beach one but I only encountered the one suburbia level (Nyarlathotep found a sad, empty beach!). There are maybe a dozen or so townsfolk and cops wandering around (police are denoted by blue shirts and wide brimmed hats, naturally), and once they're dead they're gone for the day. They just meander in the street waiting 'blah, blah, blahing' until you, the player character, give them the sweet release of death. When the shooting (or slashing/cutting) starts they just run in circles, and the cops charge mindlessly – easily picked off with a single shotgun shot from across the map.

Or you could just drive around and slam into them, the AI doesn't really know how to deal with it.

And then there are buildings... houses, shops, the plant, a bank – but it's all really desolate. There is a distinct lack of assets, particularly glaring in the offices at the power plant. It feels really hollow.

I just can't recommend it. I'm gonna keep my eye on this and update my review but it currently resembles my bottle of reviewing tequila: empty. There's some great pop culture references, the ragdoll/slow down/physics shenanigans are great, the voxel style is cool, and the general idea is fun, but it's all so much potential and no substance. The mele weapons swing like the crowbar in Half Life and cause ridiculous sparks, the sound of your footsteps is the same regardless of the surface you're walking on, the game resets rather abruptly when the day is up, the AI is as dumb as a bag of  rocks in remedial rock class...

I guess what I'm trying to say is Garbage Day is a new indie title with a really cool concept, so dig it: you're a shlub that lives in suburbia, workin' at the nuclear power plant. Everything is great until something goes wrong and you find yourself stuck in a temporal loop, reliving the same day over and over, again and again and again and again.

Ad infinitum.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

tl;dr: Very early in development, but the sandbox mode is great fun. It'll be amazing when more is added, but the story mode seems like a one-time thing. Once you beat it, why play it more? Just get it for sandbox, probably. 20 minutes of gameplay link at end of review (with no facecam!).

---

As you can tell by the average playtime (~60 minutes) there's not a whole lot of game to go off of right now as it's still in development. As such, I'm reviewing not what's currently in-game but what the potential is. Currently, it's just a sandbox to kill an hour with.

The story mode is not yet implemented, but sounds pretty straight-forward. I fear that once you beat the story once there's no reason to ever go back into it unless there's randomization to the actors, building locations, and a pool of solutions from which one is chosen. Replayability is out the window without sandbox.

The sandbox mode a terrific fun. First off, the game uses Unreal Engine so the majority of what's being interacted with is physics-based using PhysX. While it's all very simple right now, with some polishing further in development crashing a car through fences and trees has the potential to be different every time. Blowing up a building, destroying a wall, bashing down a door, etc will always good fun and this leads to sandbox being a fantastic thing to jump into and mess around to kill some time.

Artistically, the game's... unique. I don't quite know what it reminds me of, but I get a serious toy-town vibe from it. Everything's so smooth it's like I'm in a plastic world. At first I hated it, but it really started to grow on me. If the bloom stays on its leash it's really quite pretty. Another review had complaints on the game not running well, but personally I had no issues. System resources being used were minimal until I flipped a lightswitch, and only then did the framerate drop. This is a pretty minor complaint, though - this early in development it's a wonder I hit 60fps at all. For that reason I'm leaving out the fact the game crashes fairly consistently after several minutes as that'll no doubt be smoothed out further in development.

The slow motion is a really neat feature that I think a lot of people are ignoring. I can't put into words how fun it was doing certain maneuvers to kill several cops within seconds during slow-motion, let alone doing donuts with the car. If the physics gets to the point where we can smash a car through the bank and watch the bricks fly, it'll be a fine cinematic experience.

$15 USD might seem a bit high, but at least put the game on the wish list so you don't forget about it. I get the feeling this is one of those games certain YouTubers will pick up and mess around with and folks'll think Wow

Early Access Review

As much as I still play this game, and as good as the idea of the game (To me Atleast) is, Garbage Day just doesn't have the content right now. Do not get me wrong, The gameplay is fun, and it has a lot of potential. But as the game stands, there isn't enough gameplay to keep coming back. How many times is Robbing the Bank, or Murdering the Entire Town, or Throwing yourself from the Highest Tower, Or Visiting the Desert going to Be fun?

The Last update by the Dev was on 3rd of Febuary, 2016, about Future Updates we just haven't Seen. The Dev says they want to release the story as a whole, but with lack of updates over 3 months, it's hard to feel if the project is even being continued. If there was more to it, or even a update of any kind, I would feel better about the project, but as it stands, there just isn't enough there to pay CDN$16.99 on what is, in it's current state, a Demo of a game.
